case_vignette: A 67-year-old-male farmer presents complaining of a growing mole on the right side of his cheek.   He states the mole was present for several years, but then started growing rapidly on one side a few weeks ago. Sometimes the mole will bleed on its own. He tries to avoid picking at the area.   Physical examination shows tan-brown ovoid irreuglarly shaped hyperpigmented macule with focal ulcearion. Dermoscopy demonstrates a blue-gray veil in the center of the lesion.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a growing mole on the right side of my cheek that has started to bleed sometimes on its own.
How long have you noticed the mole, and has it changed in color, size, or shape recently?
The mole has been there for several years, but it started growing rapidly on one side a few weeks ago.
Have you noticed any other new skin changes or moles elsewhere on your body?
No, I haven't noticed any other new skin changes or moles elsewhere on my body.
Do you have any personal or family history of skin cancer?
I have not mentioned any personal or family history of skin cancer.
Has the mole become itchy or painful recently?
No, the mole has not become itchy or painful.
Final Diagnosis: Melanoma
